) is a town and municipality in
, the centre of which is the only real (although small) town in the
, which to a large part belongs to the municipality.

The town has a tradition of regarding itself the capital of (the south-west part of) the archipelago. There is a wooden old town, a giant limestone quarry by the centre (origin of Nordkalk Corporation and its siblings), industry and rural country-side. Much of the central and most of the outer archipelago and thus most of the Archipelago Sea National Park belongs to Pargas. Pargas consists of the former municipalities Pargas,
speaking area. Because of the industry (later: proximity to Turku), though, there are nearly as many

speaking in the town. The municipality is officially bilingual and you get service in both languages nearly everywhere.

As in the rest of Finland you get along in English with most people.

value: Pargas centre seen from the turnabout on the Archipelago road.

Pargas centre is some 25 kilometres from

.

The only road to Pargas is
), starting at national road 1 (E18) and crossing regional road 110, both leading from

to Turku. There is a bike route all the way from Turku, mostly following the road.

There is a ferry connection from Långnäs on

to Galtby in Korpo. You can continue by the road, with two shorter ferry passages.

There are connections also from the north, at least in summer, via
and Iniö to Houtskär and via
to Nagu, and from there to Pargas along Skärgårdsvägen. The main connections are part of

("the Archipelago circle road") marketed to tourists, with some capacity for cars. There may be connections via Iniö and Houtskär also in the winter, calling at several small islands, sometimes using hovercraft or hydrocopters. The most convenient route is via Turku any part of the year, unless you are visiting some of the islands en route.

value: Buses of Vainion Liikenne and Skärgårdsvägen at Pargas bus station.

operates the coach connections. The coaches via Pargas centre onwards to Nagu, Korpo and Houtskär are usually in the green colours of Skärgårdsvägen Ab, while those that terminate in the centre are in the yellow colour of Vainio proper. The latter are often city buses without proper luggage holds. The fare Turku–Pargas is 6€ for adults, 3€ for children (less than 12 years), 3€(?) for a bike (transported if there is room).

From Turku, there are connections at least

value: to Pargas centre every hour (a quarter past), except some hours in the night, every half an hour daytime except Sundays
via Pargas centre farther on to the archipelago (Skärgårdsvägen), a few times a day

There are also some direct services from

, and services from Helsinki with transfer in Kaarina, usually at Piispanristi. For Vainio coaches from Helsinki the transfers are "official": direct tickets can be bought from the driver and the transfer is announced. With other companies you might have to buy the tickets in advance from Matkahuolto (make sure the ticket seller knows about the transfer) to avoid paying for separate tickets.

The bus station is by the roundabout on Skärgårdsvägen, by the north end of the centre. The buses terminating here drive through the centre.

Pargas is a good destination also by yacht, but note the bridges. Getting to Turku via the centre of Pargas is somewhat awkward with sailing vessels (a long passage in narrow sounds).

Marinas e.g.

value: directions=at the south end of the centre, by Kyrkfjärden
directions=Stormälö, in the south-east end of the Airisto body of water

content=Marina near the big fareways to Turku, by hotel Airisto Strand and a large cottage village, but otherwise in the middle of nowhere. A mile – by sea – to the Archipelago road with some coach connections. Get lift by boat or car if you want to get anywhere by land.

The town itself is not too big. Most services are by the
sound from the roundabout on Skärgårdsvägen to the marina in the south) or nearby, especially in the pedestrian street

. The old town is across the sound.

There is a zone with residential areas around the centre. Some services such as sport venues, beaches and the health care centre are here, in a radius of about one kilometre.

For the area outside town the options are more or less bike, car or taxi (boat for some destinations). There are also school buses and other arrangements for locals, which you might be able to use with some detective work – and of course the coaches from Turku.

The taxi station is in the southern end of the centre, by Kyrksundet.

content=Wooden old town by the church.
hours=June and July: Sun–Thu 11.00–16.00; other times by request;  large groups should announce their arrival beforehand
content=Museum café. Former home of Fredrika Tengström (later Runeberg; 1807–1879), writer and wife of the national poet.

Most accommodation businesses also arrange activities.

value: Outdoor sports: swimming, beach volley, golf, horseback riding, boating, canoeing, fishing

Most shops can be found in Köpmansgatan, a few near the church, some by Strandgatan or farther away.

For souvenirs, consider e.g.

value: directions=6 km from the centre towards Turku, 2 km from the Archipelago road
content=Sheep farm with quite pricey but excellent products from yarn and mittens to fur coats and art. Coffee served in a nice milieu. Sheep available for caressing.

Most restaurants are in the centre, in the pedestrian street Köpmansgatan or nearby. Consider also cafés and restaurants in the See, Buy and Sleep sections.

There are two large grocery stores (K-market Reimari and S-market) by the north part of the centre.

Market in the centre (market square by the taxi station) Saturday mornings, summertime also Wednesday evenings. Not many sellers, but often some fish, berries and mushrooms.

directions=6 km from the centre towards Turku, 2,6 km from the Archipelago road
content=Restaurant and hotel in old villa; open in summer or by request by groups.
directions=9 km from the centre westwards along the Archipelago road, just after the high Sattmark bridge
content=Nice café, marina for guests, fresh and smoked fish, nature path. Cabins for 1–4 persons.
directions=north of the Archipelgo road, before the turnabout of Pargas centre if coming from Turku

Area code 2. Good GSM coverage in the town. In the outer archipelago and some rural areas there may be local lack of signal.

Postal code 21600 Pargas for the town with surroundings (the area of the formal municipality).
